report_title: Hazardous Waste Collection in the US
executive_summary: Hazardous waste collection service has benefited from rising industrial and utilities construction activity. As these sectors have expanded, they have produced more hazardous waste, boosting service demand. Also, individuals and households frequently employ waste collection services to ensure proper household hazardous waste disposal. Industry-wide revenue has increased at an expected CAGR of 2.7% to reach $2.9 billion over the five years to 2024, with revenue set to rise 0.5% in 2024 as profit remains stable.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Hazardous Waste Collection is Unaffected by Macroeconomic Downturns
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Waste collection services are considered essential and are cushioned from broader macroeconomic declines. This contributed to the Hazardous Waste Collection industry's steady revenue growth amid the broad macroeconomic disruption caused by the COVID-19 pandemic.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: THE EFFECTS OF REGULATION ARE TWOFOLD
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Commercial, industrial and construction companies will continue to hire hazardous waste collectors to ensure compliance with new codes as the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and state agencies continue to update rules. The increasing stringency of hazardous waste collection and disposal regulations is a boon for the industry.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: THE VOLATILE NATURE OF OIL PRICES IMPACTS HAZARDOUS WASTE COLLECTION SERVICES
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Fluctuations in the price of oil have a significant impact on the industry. Diesel fuel powers most hazardous waste collection vehicles and is the largest component of the industry's purchase spending.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: DOWNSTREAM MARKET GROWTH WILL BENEFIT HAZARDOUS WASTE COLLECTION SERVICES
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The value of utility and private nonresidential construction will grow in the coming years, generating more hazardous waste and translating into greater need for hazardous waste collection.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Infrastructure Bills Will Create Need for Collection Services
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Construction companies, for power, water and sewage and commercial building projects, demand services before, during and after construction. Hazardous waste collection services are required both to remove waste for safety reasons, as well as to ensure buildings and infrastructure are in compliance with regulations put forth by the Environmental Protection Agency.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Efforts to Reduce Hazardous Waste Production Rather Than Manage It Will Boost
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Environmental awareness will continue rising, prompting consumers and corporations to seek ways to produce less hazardous waste, curbing demand for the industry and mitigating revenue growth.

industry_definition: This industry collects and hauls hazardous waste locally and operates hazardous waste transfer stations. Industry activities include hazardous waste collection services; radioactive waste collection and hauling services; hazardous waste transfer stations; hazardous waste hauling services. Hazardous waste collection service excludes establishments whose primary service is hazardous waste treatment or that collect and haul hazardous waste with disposal services.
key_trends: The industry primarily competes based on price. The pricing for services offered by the industry is affected by the frequency of hazardous waste collection and its general volume or weight.

Externally, the industry competes primarily with government counties and municipalities. Governments can access tax revenue and have tax-exempt financing for their hazardous waste collection operations if they so choose.

market_segmentation.segment_description: This segment primarily includes government and nonprofit organizations and household consumers. demand_determinants.determinant_title: The utility sector produces hazardous waste
demand_determinants.determinant_description: The utility sector produces hazardous waste that requires collection services. The utility sector includes constructing power, sewage and water supply infrastructure. Increased utility construction activity tends to lead to higher demand.

regulations_points.regulation_description: RCRA establishes a regulatory framework for transporting, treating, storing and disposing of hazardous and non-hazardous solid waste.
This act established the basic structure for regulating pollutant discharges into the waters of the United States.
The CAA regulates emissions of air pollutants; it includes emission standards for vehicles, including collection trucks.
The TSCA allows the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to require reporting, record-keeping, testing requirements and restrictions relating to chemical substances or mixtures.
OSHA gave the federal government the authority to set and enforce safety and health standards for most of the country's workers.

basis_points.basis_description: The industry primarily competes based on price. The pricing for services offered by the industry is affected by the frequency of hazardous waste collection and its general volume or weight.

Externally, the industry competes primarily with government counties and municipalities. Governments can access tax revenue and have tax-exempt financing for their hazardous waste collection operations if they so choose.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Most prominent companies have expanded their market shares through mergers and acquisitions. Competition based on acquisitions has increased the price of investments and made it advantageous to be a larger company with more significant resources and access to capital.

Larger companies have been disposing of operations with lower profit while purchasing other businesses to improve efficiency and take advantage of economies of scale. Consolidation made it more difficult for smaller businesses to gain market share and compete in regional markets.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Higher Fuel Prices Boost Industry Costs
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchase costs include equipment, proper protection and all necessary materials and supplies. The largest cost for the industry is fuel, required for collection vehicles to pick up and transport waste. Volatility in fuel prices has had a negative effect on purchase costs, especially as fuel costs rose early in the current period. Still, companies have made efforts at consolidation to cut costs.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Profit is Dependent on a Company's Ability to Accurately Estimate the Cost of a Project
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Profit is subject to fluctuations because of compliance costs associated with increasing regulation from government entities like the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). Many large contracts given to the industry are at a fixed price and don't necessarily reflect the actual costs incurred. Still, the current period has seen margins remain stable across the industry, in line with steady demand for hazardous waste collection.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Hazardous Waste Service is Labor Intensive
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Drivers' salaries and payments to subcontractors are the main components of wage costs for business owners. The industry is increasingly focusing on automation to create efficiencies in workflow and helps to lower wage costs.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Capital remains central to the waste collection services, driven by significant investment in collection vehicles, containers and transfer stations. Wage costs are relatively high given that many employees are needed to operate.

volatility_points.volatility_title: CHANGES IN HAZARDOUS WASTE GENERATION CAN IMPACT REVENUE
volatility_points.volatility_description: Revenue is directly related to hazardous waste, produced fairly consistently because of population growth, utility construction growth, new business formation and industrial output. Businesses and individuals continually demand hazardous waste collection services regardless of price changes, limiting the influence of macroeconomic fluctuations on industry revenue.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: WASTE COLLECTION TRUCK INNOVATION IMPROVES EFFICIENCY
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Companies have invested significantly in innovation to make their hazardous waste collection vehicles more energy-efficient to reduce costs and minimize environmental impact. Most waste collection trucks now have lifting devices that automatically lift and empty waste containers into the truck, reducing operating costs and the likelihood of employee injury.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in a niche service or bundle its services to attract clients?
FAQs.answer: Hazardous waste collection companies specialize in collecting and transferring hazardous waste, servicing a range of downstream customers including construction, industrial and commercial companies and households.

FAQs.question: Does your company have any marketing campaigns in place to attract clients?
FAQs.answer: Marketing costs tend to be low in this industry.

FAQs.question: Has the trend in business outsourcing positively impacted your company? Do you see this trend continuing in the future?
FAQs.answer: Increased outsourcing of municipal collection services to private companies has benefited the industry and will continue to as local governments seek to cut costs. Companies increasingly hire outside hazardous waste collectors because of their specialization rather than rely on in-house operators.

FAQs.question: Has your company implemented practices to lower purchasing costs?
FAQs.answer: Players have invested in automation and technology regarding fuel efficiency and truck design.

FAQs.question: Does your company target a particular market segment or provide for a broad range of markets?
FAQs.answer: Hazardous waste collectors provide services for a broad range of customers, but the vast majority of revenue is generated from commercial, industrial, and construction customers.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce costs through automation?
FAQs.answer: While automation has increased, the industry is still very labor-intensive as many employees are needed to operate vehicles, sort through different types of hazardous waste and ensure timely delivery.

FAQs.question: Does your business use web-based systems for customer bookings or orders?
FAQs.answer: Most companies have established online platforms making it easier for customers to manage and schedule their accounts and pick-up times.

FAQs.question: Do regulations pertinent to your business vary from state to state?
FAQs.answer: While some regulations vary from state to state, most laws impacting the industry come from the federal government. This regulation includes the Water Pollution Control Act, the Clean Air Act and the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure the health and safety of its employees?
FAQs.answer: Companies work with industry associations, such as the Solid Waste Association of North America and the Environmental Protection Agency, to stay up to date on changing regulations regarding the industry and workplace.

FAQs.question: How frequently does your company purchase new equipment?
FAQs.answer: Hazardous waste collection is fairly capital-intensive, since most players need to invest heavily in collection, sorting, transfer and waste disposable. Therefore, equipment requires regular maintenance and repair, adding to depreciation costs.

FAQs.question: How does your company maintain profit?
FAQs.answer: Profit declines as fuel prices increase and players spend a larger portion of their budget to purchase costs, specifically for their vehicle fleets.

FAQs.question: How does your company maintain its reputation? How do you retain repeat customers?
FAQs.answer: Having a high prior success rate (including completed prior contracts). It's crucial for hazardous waste collection companies to have repeat clients, which means effectively managing a company's reputation.

FAQs.question: How does your company comply with the ever-changing regulatory landscape?
FAQs.answer: Must comply with government regulations. Players must comply with regulatory policies regarding hazardous waste management, which can be costly to some companies if mistakes are made.

FAQs.question: How does your company control costs to maintain revenue and profit margins?
FAQs.answer: Effective cost controls. Purchase costs eat into profit, so it's crucial for players to keep purchases as low as they can.

FAQs.question: What proportion of your revenue is derived from fuel surcharges? How do you plan for volatile fuel prices? How will you mitigate this threat?
FAQs.answer: Fuel is the primary input cost for this industry, as it's used to power the trucks that carry out the majority of hazardous waste collection services that this industry supplies.

FAQs.question: How closely does your company monitor trends in population?
FAQs.answer: Many hazardous waste products are generated in residential properties, so hazardous waste generation is driven by population growth.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor changes in the value of utilities construction? How has growth in utilities construction influenced your demand?
FAQs.answer: The utility sector produces hazardous waste that requires the industry's services.
